children.text: Eightieth session
Item 137 of the preliminary list*
Proposed programme budget for 2026 – Proposed programme budget for 2026
Part II – Political affairs
Section 3
Political affairs
Special political missions – United Nations Assistance Mission for Iraq

table_content.text: The present report contains the proposed resource requirements for 2026 for the liquidation of the United Nations Assistance Mission for Iraq in the amount of $38,041,000 (net of staff assessment).

children.text: **	The part consisting of the proposed programme plan for 2026 is submitted for the consideration of the General Assembly in accordance with the established budgetary procedures and practices reaffirmed in paragraph 7 of Assembly resolution 77/267.

***	In keeping with paragraph 10 of General Assembly resolution 77/267, the part consisting of the post and non-post resource requirements is submitted through the Advisory Committee on Administrative and Budgetary Questions for the consideration of the General Assembly.
I. 	Overview of the Mission

text: A.	Planned activities for 2026 and programme performance in 2024

children.text: Overall orientation
Mandates and background

The mandate of the United Nations Assistance Mission for Iraq (UNAMI) was established by the Security Council in its resolution 1483 (2003) and extended in subsequent resolutions of the Council. In its resolution 2732 (2024), the Security Council decided to extend UNAMI’s mandate for a final 19-month period until 31 December 2025, after which UNAMI will cease all work and operations except with respect to any remaining liquidation of the Mission. In addition, the Council decided to authorize the retention of guard units from within UNAMI’s existing footprint to protect the Mission’s personnel, facilities and assets, including during the liquidation period.

The transition and liquidation plan of the Secretary-General for UNAMI, prepared in consultation with the Government of Iraq, submitted to the Security Council on 24 December 2024 (S/2024/966, annex), identified, among the strategic transition priorities, a safe and gradual mission drawdown by 31 December 2025.

By the end of its drawdown period, UNAMI is expected to complete the handover of tasks to the United Nations country team, physically close and environmentally clean up two locations (Mosul and Kirkuk). The office in Basra is located in a hotel and will be closed by 31 December and returned to its original state and to its owner by end of January 2026. UNAMI remains on schedule to complete the physical verification of majority of its assets, and disposal of assets through transfer, gifting, and sale, as per the applicable United Nations Financial Regulations and Rules, the repatriation of 215 United Nations Guard Unit personnel and their equipment and separation of civilian staff in line with the drawdown plan, except those to be retained to support the liquidation activities.

As of 1 January 2026, the liquidation period will start and will address all residual matters after the Mission’s closure on 31 December 2025. A liquidation team will be required until 30 September 2026 to address residual liquidation activities not completed during the drawdown phase of the Mission and to ensure due diligence is exercised throughout the liquidation processes. These liquidation activities include but are not limited to asset disposal, repatriation of remaining contingent-owned equipment, environmental cleanup, engineering maintenance/refurbishment of the premises in the three locations in Baghdad (Tamimi Compound, United Nations Integrated Compound in Baghdad and Forward Support Base) and the compounds in Erbil and Kuwait  to be handed over to the government or the United Nations country team, and the separation or transfer to other UN entities of personnel, and movement of United Nations owned equipment.

Emphasis will also be placed on finalising administrative tasks, such as resolving/closing outstanding claims and payments and completing archiving processes, before the end of the liquidation period. The objective is to minimise the workload to be transferred to the Regional Service Centre in Entebbe, Uganda (RSCE) and the United Nations Headquarters.
Programme of work
Objective
The objective, following the closure of the Mission on 31 December 2025, is to ensure the timely conclusion of the field-based liquidation activities by 30 September 2026.
Strategy and external factors for 2026
To contribute to the objective, the liquidation team will:
(a)	Implement the liquidation plan (S/2024/966);
(b)	Complete the handing over of premises and assets to the national authorities and the United Nations country team, as appropriate;
(c)	Ensure a structured, efficient, and secure liquidation, facilitating the safe departure of civilian and military personnel from Iraq;

(d)	Preserve institutional memory and capture lessons learned by documenting and preserving knowledge gained over the Mission’s lifespan through established archiving and record management procedures.
The above-mentioned work will result in:
(a)	Meeting the 30 September 2026 deadline for the completion of the field-based liquidation activities;
(b)	Preserving an operational environment for a sustained long-term United Nations presence in Iraq and the region.
With regard to the external factors, the liquidation plan is based on the following planning assumptions:
(a) 	The security and situation remain sufficiently permissive for the safe movement of staff and removal of United Nations assets as necessary;
(b)	The United Nations country team will have sufficient capacity and access to fully absorb additional assets and premises management;
(c)	The Iraqi authorities will remain supportive of the liquidation activities throughout the agreed field-based liquidation period.
Programme performance in 2024
Inclusive engagement on the transition of the Mission

Following the adoption of Security Council resolution 2732 (2024), UNAMI realigned its efforts to focus on the four streamlined areas outlined in the mandate, including the provision of its good offices and technical assistance to the Kurdistan Region parliamentary elections held in October 2024, the promotion and protection of human rights, and facilitation of development tasks. The Mission intensified its facilitation of dialogue and progress towards the final resolution of outstanding issues between Iraq and Kuwait, in preparation to address the Security Council’s request to the Secretary-General to make recommendations for an ‘appropriate follow-on mechanism’. The Mission simultaneously began its work to prepare, in consultation with the Government of Iraq, the Secretary-General’s transition and liquidation plan for submission to the Security Council by 31 December 2024, which took into consideration three strategic transition priorities to guide the work of the United Nations system in Iraq as it phases out UNAMI: (a) effective mandate delivery; (b) transfer of tasks to ensure preservation of gains and sustained United Nations support; and (c) safe and gradual mission drawdown by the end of December 2025.
Progress towards the objective is presented in the performance measure below (see table 1).
Table 1 – Performance measure

table_content.text: Progress made towards residual mandated tasks including the coordinated engagement with the Government of Iraq on transition and finalization of a transition and liquidation plan.

children.text: Planned activities during the liquidation period in 2026
Major liquidation activities during the period from 1 January to 30 September 2026 will include the following:

Physically close and conduct the environmental remediation and handover of the two liquidation locations (Basra and Kuwait).  The Tehran Liaison Office will be closed in February 2026, and where feasible, residual activities will be transferred to UNAMA.
Repatriate the remaining 30 guard unit personnel by 30 September 2026, with their contingent-owned equipment;
Administratively separate all remaining civilian personnel associated with the liquidation process by 30 September 2026;
Reconcile and close financial records, as well as the settlement of legal and administrative cases, as applicable;
Transfer and dispose of archived paper records by 30 June 2026;
Dispose of assets (property, plant and equipment, and inventory) in line with the provisions of the United Nations Financial Regulations and Rules and the asset disposition plan.

UNAMI will establish service-level agreements during 2025 with the Regional Service Centre in Entebbe and the United Nations Logistics Base at Brindisi, Italy, which will govern the range of support services provided during the liquidation and post-field-based liquidation periods. The support will continue throughout the post-field-based liquidation period to reconcile records, prepare a final asset disposition report, and provide residual administrative and financial activities. The progress of the provision of support services by the Regional Service Centre in Entebbe and the United Nations Logistics Base at Brindisi, Italy throughout the field-based liquidation period will be monitored through weekly meetings.

The current mission locations in Baghdad, Erbil, and Kuwait will become the sole operational facilities for the liquidation team as of 1 January 2026. From these locations, the liquidation team will work in conjunction with other teams in Kuwait and the United Nations Logistics Base, to execute liquidation tasks.
Proposed composition of the liquidation team
The liquidation team is proposed to be constituted by the retention of 135 existing posts (detailed in para 17 to 21 below).

On 1 January 2026, the Resident Coordinator/ Humanitarian Coordinator (Assistant Secretary-General) will become the highest-ranking United Nations representative in Iraq and will assume the functions of the Head of Entity. As Head of the Entity, for the period 1 January to 31 May 2026, he or she will lead the overall governance, coordination, and maintenance of communication with the relevant authorities.  During this period, this post will continue to be funded at 50 per cent and cost-shared with the Development Coordination Office, in line with the established arrangement for similar triple-hatted posts.

The front office of the Head of Entity will comprise 3 posts (1 P-4, 1 Field Service and 1 National Professional Officer), who will provide support to the Resident Coordinator/Humanitarian Coordinator in his/her capacity as Head of Entity.

Five posts comprising 2 P-4, 1 P-3 and 2 National Professional Officer will be responsible for a range of critical functions, including liaising with the Government of Iraq, implementing the Conduct and Discipline strategies and oversight, providing legal advice and translation services, and providing guidance on the liquidation team’s communication strategy in coordination with the front office of the Head of the Entity. Their role will ensure that key legal, and public information aspects of the closure are effectively managed.

The current post of Chief of Mission Support (D-1) will assist the Head of Entity from 1 January to 31 May 2026 in managing the liquidation team. From 1 June to 30 September 2026, the Chief of Mission Support will head the Liquidation Team. The Chief of Mission Support will carry out performance monitoring and reporting and stewardship of human, financial and physical resources in compliance with the Financial Regulations and Rules and the Staff Regulations and Rules of the United Nations. The Chief of Mission Support will be assisted by pillar heads covering service delivery, operation and resource management, and security.  The mission support component of the liquidation team is proposed to be composed of 87 posts (1 D-1, 2 P-5, 8 P-4, 4 P-3, 22 Field Service, 12 National Professional Officer and 38 Local level).

In terms of security, a security team of 15 personnel will be retained to provide protection and carry out activities such as securing mission assets, mission-related investigations, inspections, protection and essential fire-safety services. The team includes two Close Protection Officers, and three Field Security Assistants dedicated to providing security for the Resident Coordinator/Humanitarian Coordinator serving as the Head of Entity, both within and outside United Nations compounds.  The security team would be supplemented by the retention of the United Nations Guard Unit composed of 30 guard unit personnel responsible for the protection of United Nations personnel, assets and facilities within the internal perimeter of the liquidation two locations.

A team of 24 posts (2 P-4, 1 P-3, 3 Field Services and 18 Local level) in the Kuwait Joint Support Office (KJSO) will continue to provide critical back-office support in travel, finance and human resources.  In view of the termination of the mandate of UNAMI on 31 December 2025, it is the intention of the Secretariat to transition the peace operations supported by the KJSO to the RSCE by the end of the UNAMI’s liquidation by 30 September 2026. The retention of the currently encumbered posts is to ensure sufficient capacity is available to prepare for and implement the transition, aligned with the projected timeline for the complete liquidation of UNAMI.

Temporary surge capacity will be provided by the Department of Operational Support which will provide support and coordination between United Nations Headquarters and United Nations Logistics Base at Brindisi, with occasional deployment to Iraq and Kuwait.

The selection process for personnel for the Liquidation Team will consider the existing personnel and the skill sets relevant to the liquidation period. UNAMI (and the liquidation team after UNAMI’s closure) will continue to support the placement of separating national staff for consideration by other entities within the United Nations in Iraq, through sharing the list of national staff with the United Nations country team and by broadcasting to these staff the information on job openings posted by other organizations. A National Staff Capacity Building Programme was strategically designed to equip national staff with essential skills and support for successful career transitions ahead of mission closure. Key initiatives already implemented in 2024 and 2025 include: (a) the comprehensive assessment of staff skills, which considers the current skills and learning needs of staff and how this aligns to the local market; (b) job search and application training in collaboration with local recruiters, vocational and technical certifications such as the International Computer Driving License; and (c) entrepreneurial workshops by Business by Design, personalized career coaching, mentorship, and a Training Newsletter which provides up to date information on job opportunities across United Nations and non-United Nations entities. Other activities planned for 2025 include virtual and in-person career fairs, launching of a dedicated job platform application tool, and expanded vocational training and collaboration with the United Nations country team on  vocational training and business start-ups.

The size and composition of the team during the liquidation will be progressively reduced through the abolishment of posts. It is proposed that, 10 staff members will be separated by 31 May 2026, 22 by 30 June 2026, and 103 by 30 September 2026. This process will continue in parallel with the closure of the liquidation team’s office in Erbil by 30 June 2026, and the office in Baghdad and the office in Kuwait by 30 September 2026, which will mark the end of the field-based liquidation activities.

Thereafter, there would still be residual liquidation activities such as asset reconciliation, the completion of derecognition and deactivation of property records, the preparation of inputs for the final disposition of assets which would be undertaken by the United Nations Logistics Base at Brindisi, Italy.  At the Headquarters level, the Department of Operational Support will lead the overall monitoring and analysis of the progress of the completion of the residual liquidation activities. The Department of Management Strategy, Policy and Compliance will coordinate the preparation and submission of financial and budget performance reporting after the closure of the 2026 financial period, in early 2027. The two Departments will continue to support the liquidation period on aspects related to the liquidation, including coordination with different teams at Headquarters and reporting to senior management stakeholders and legislative bodies.

Additional support during liquidation will be provided through the deployment of personnel on temporary duty assignment, general temporary assistance or individual contractors, including at the Regional Service Centre in Entebbe, Uganda, and the United Nations Logistics Base at Brindisi, Italy, as necessary.
The clinic managed by the United Nations country team will provide medical services to staff operating in Baghdad on a cost recovery basis until 30 September 2026.

text: B.	 	Proposed post and non-post resource requirements in 2026

children.text: 1.	Total resource requirements
Resource requirements (regular budget) – Table 2 – Financial resources
(Thousands of United States dollars)
Table 3 – Drawdown of human resources
a	One position is funded at 50 per cent and cost-shared with the Development Coordination Office.

The proposed resource requirements for liquidation activities in 2026 amount to $38,041,000 (net of staff assessment). The proposed requirements would provide for: (a) military and police personnel costs related to the 30 United Nations guard unit personnel to be withdrawn by 30 September 2026 ($818,500); (b) staff salaries, common staff costs and danger pay ($32,346,100) for the gradual separation of 135 civilian personnel encumbered as at 1 January 2026 to be retained for the liquidation team, consisting of 55 international staff (1 ASG, 1 D-1, 2 P-5, 14 P-4,6 P-3 and 31 Field Service) and 80 national staff (15 National Professional Officer and 65 Local level), including $19 million for estimated  payments due to staff members at the time of separation or relocation, inclusive of $11.3 million relating to the remaining estimated payments due to staff members to be separated in 2025, for which only a partial provision was approved in the 2025 budget, as well as a provision for of $882,400 for surge capacity in the Department of Operational Support; and (c) operational costs ($4,817,000).
The phased separation of the liquidation team comprising 135 posts is detailed below:

Abolishment, as at 31 May 2026, of 10 posts, comprising the post of the Head of Entity/Resident Coordinator/ Humanitarian Coordinator (ASG), his support team, namely, one Special Assistant (P-4), one Administrative Assistant (Field Service) one Assistant Coordination Officer (National Professional Officer), as well as two Close Protection Officers (Field Service) and three Field Security Assistant (Local level) that provide dedicated security support to the Head of Entity. In addition, one Logistics Officer (National Professional Officer) in the Office of the Chief of Mission Support will also be abolished.

Abolishment, as at 30 June 2026, of 22 posts (1 P-4, 1 P-3, 4 Field Service, 5 National Professional Officer and 11 Local level), with functions that covers public communications, protocol, movement and control, property management, procurement and environment.

Abolishment, as at 30 September 2026, of 103 posts (1 D-1, 2 P-5, 12 P-4, 5 P-3, 24 Field Service, 8 National Professional Officers, and 51 Local Level). During the field-based liquidation period up to 30 September 2026, these posts will perform a range of functions that include legal, conduct and discipline, security, finance and budget, human resources, communication and information technology, property management, travel and administration, inclusive of 24 posts in KJSO.

In addition, provision is made for surge capacity in the Department of Operational Support and United Nations Logistics Base at Brindisi, Italy for five general temporary assistance personnel comprising: one Human Resource Officer and one Programme Management Officer both at the P-4 level, one Programme Management Officer and one Supply Chain Planning Officer both at the P-3 level; and one Senior Property Management Assistant (General Service, Principal level).
Vacancy rates

The cost estimates for the United Nations guard units takes into consideration the full deployment during the liquidation period and repatriation by 30 September 2026 of the 30 guard unit personnel. For civilian personnel, the cost estimates for the period 1 January to 30 September 2026 are based on the assumption of full incumbency during the liquidation period, and the phased abolishment of posts outlined in para 29 above.
2.	Financial resources
Table 4 – Financial resources by category of expenditure
(Thousands of United States dollars)
3.	Analysis of resource requirements
Military and police personnel costs
(Thousands of United States dollars)

The reduced requirements are attributable primarily to the gradual withdrawal of United Nations guard unit personnel, in accordance with the liquidation plan. The proposed resources include provision for 30 personnel retained until 30 September 2026 for the field-based liquidation period, compared to the provision made for 245 personnel until 31 July 2025 and 157 personnel until 31 December 2025 in the approved budget for 2025.
Civilian personnel costs
(Thousands of United States dollars)

The reduced requirements are attributable to the phased separation of international staff, except for a smaller staffing complement of personnel retained to complete the liquidation by 30 September 2026. The reduced requirements are offset in part by the inclusion of a provision of $16.2 million for payments due to staff members upon separation from services, including $9.2 million for staff members to be separated in 2025, for which only a partial provision was approved in the 2025 budget.

The reduced requirements are attributable to the phased separation of staff, except for 1 National Professional Officers retained to complete the liquidation by 30 September 2026. The reduced requirements are offset in part by the inclusion of a provision of $1.7 million for payments due to staff members upon separation of services, including $1.5 million for staff members to be separated in 2025, for which only a partial provision was approved in the 2025 budget.

The reduced requirements are attributable to the phased separation of staff, except for 65 Local level staff retained to complete the liquidation by 30 September 2026. The reduced requirements are offset in part by the inclusion of a provision of $1.2 million for payments due to staff members upon separation of services, including $601,600 for staff members to be separated in 2025, for which only a partial provision was approved in the 2025 budget.
No resources are proposed for United Nations Volunteers as the two positions were downsized in 2025.

Resources amounting to $882,400 are proposed to provide for surge capacity for five general temporary assistance positions (2 P-4, 2 P-3 and 1 General Service) to support the liquidation activities, including after the field-based liquidation activities have ended on 30 September 2026.  The capacity requirements have been identified by the Department of Operational Support and will encompass activities related to human resources, data analysis and management and property management.
Operational costs
(Thousands of United States dollars)
No provision is included for consultants and consulting services for the liquidation period.

The reduced requirements are attributable primarily to a lower volume of travel during the liquidation period, which will be limited to travel to carry out liquidation activities and for the deployment of staff on temporary duty assignment from United Nations Headquarters to ensure the timely finalization of liquidation tasks.

The reduced requirements are attributable primarily to a smaller scope of activities related to facilities and infrastructure after the closure and handover to relevant authorities of five locations during 2025, and a smaller staffing complement during the liquidation period. Accordingly, the demand for utilities, disposal services, maintenance, security services and construction, as well as demand for fuel for generators, is expected to decrease.

The reduced requirements are attributable primarily to: (a) the non-requirement of spare parts; (b) lower requirements for petrol, oil and lubricants owing to the smaller staffing complement during the liquidation period and the planned reduction in the fleet of the United Nations-owned vehicles; and (c) lower requirement for the rental of special purpose vehicles following the completion of closure activities in 2025.

The reduced requirements are offset in part by higher requirements for the repairs and maintenance in connection with the planned destruction/ cannibalization of armored vehicles that will not be disposed through transfer to other United Nations entities.
No provision is included for air operations for the liquidation period as the current aircraft contract will be discontinued in 2025.

The reduced requirements are attributable primarily to the smaller staffing complement and phased withdrawal of personnel during the liquidation period, resulting in lower requirements for telecommunications and network services, the maintenance of communications and information technology equipment and support services, software, licenses and fees, public information and production services, and spare parts.

The reduced requirements are offset in part by the cost of refurbishment of 71 high-value electronic counter-measure equipment identified for transfer to the strategic deployment stock for inclusion into the return-refurbish-reuse programme at the United Nations Logistics Base in Brindisi for storage and potential transfer to other peacekeeping and special political missions.

The reduced requirements are attributable to the smaller staffing complement and phased withdrawal of personnel during the liquidation period, resulting in reduced requirements for medical services and the non-requirement for supplies owing to stock availability.

The reduced requirements are attributable mainly to the smaller staffing complement, which resulted in lower requirements training fees, supplies and services, welfare and rations, as well as lower requirements for bank charges due to lower overall anticipated volume of transactions. The reduced requirements were offset in part by higher requirements for freight costs owing to a provision to cover the shipment of assets to United Nations Logistics Base in Brindisi, and for the shipment of archives and records.
Extrabudgetary resources
(a)	Voluntary contributions
No extrabudgetary resources are projected for 2026 due to the end of mandate in 2025.
(b)	Cost recovery

In 2025, resources in the amount of $9,251,800 are projected to be received from the United Nations country team and will continue to be utilized to provide for the continuation of six positions (two Field Service and four international United Nations Volunteers) and to continue to support the United Nations Guard Unit, cost-sharing of other security staff costs and services, space management, cleaning services, field technology services, ground transport, medical services, fuel and other supplies.
No resources are projected to be received in 2026 from the United Nations country team due to the cessation of UNAMI’s operations 31 December 2025.

text: Annex I Summary of follow-up action taken to implement decisions and requests of the General Assembly, including the requests and recommendations of the Advisory Committee on Administrative and Budgetary Questions endorsed by the Assembly

table_content.text: Action taken to implement the recommendation

Advisory Committee on Administrative and Budgetary Questions
(A/79/7/Add.48)

Advisory Committee on Administrative and Budgetary Questions
(A/79/7/Add.48)

The Advisory Committee recalls that the General Assembly recognized the importance of capacity-building for national staff in the drawdown phases of missions (see resolutions 69/258 B, 69/259 B and 67/277) and trusts that the Secretary-General will continue his efforts in this regard and will provide an update in the context of his next report on the Mission. (para. 27).

UNAMI has developed a comprehensive human resources strategy which encompasses the capacity-building for national staff to acquire new skills that can be useful in their future careers, either within or outside the United Nations. The measures already undertaken and planned initiatives for 2025 are detailed in paragraph 23 of the present report.

The Advisory Committee trusts that additional information related to UNAMI staff who were reinstated or rejoined  the Organization less than 12 months after separation, as well as any related recovery of termination indemnities, will be provided in future reports. (para.32)

As of 30 April, 40 staff have separated from UNAMI including six staff who have taken up appointment with other United Nations entities. Information on UNAMI staff who will be reinstate or rejoin the Organization less than 12 months after separation, as well as any related recovery of termination indemnities, will be reported upon in the context of future Chapeau report.

While noting that quantifiable workload information for UNAMI-funded Kuwait Joint Support Office posts would not accurately represent workload solely generated by UNAMI, the Advisory Committee is of the opinion that the service delivery model of the Office should be scalable, in that a reduction in the number of client missions and their associated transaction processing requirements should result in a reduction in the Office’s staffing. The Committee further notes that there are seven UNAMI-funded posts in the Office that are vacant. The Committee trusts that the Secretary-General will provide further justification for the retention of the 32 UNAMI-funded posts in the Office to the General Assembly in the context of its review of the present report and in his upcoming report on the liquidation requirements for the Mission (para. 44).

The General Assembly, by its resolution 79/258 B decided to abolish all vacant posts for UNAMI, including the seven vacant UNAMI-funded posts in the Kuwait Joint Support Office. 
Regarding the retention of the remaining posts, in 2024, the Department of Operational Support conducted a review of KJSO to determine how the peace operations the Office currently supports can continue to receive shared services with  efficiency, interoperability, responsiveness, and operational continuity, through the transition of UNAMI in 2025, its liquidation in 2026, and beyond. In this regard, the Secretariat intends to transition the peace operations supported by the KJSO, to the RSCE by the end of the UNAMI liquidation process, leading to the abolishment of all SPM funded posts. Details on the transition plan are presented in the context of the Chapeau report A/80/6 (Sect. 3)/Add.1.

text: Annex II Organizational structure and post distribution for 2026

children.text: Liquidation Entity at the start of liquidation period (1 January 2026)
